data.title: Passage: J. Lee Thompson, 88
data.meta_description: Thompson directed more than 50 films in his long career, including the original Cape Fear, The Guns of Navarone, a couple of Planet of the Apes sequels and a slew of Charles Bronson action movies. Thompson, a Briton, directed some of the biggest names of the mid-century, including Gregory Peck, Anthony Quinn and Yul Brynner. Despite having apprenticed under Alfred Hitchcock, who could be difficult with actors, Thompson earned a reputation as an actor's director.
data.text:
The 30 Best Movies on Max (aka HBO Max) Right Now

Love Lies Bleeding, Dune: Part Two, and Beetlejuice are just a few of the movies you should be watching on Max this month.

The 29 Best Shows on Apple TV+ Right Now

Sunny, Constellation, and Presumed Innocent are among the best shows on Apple TV+ this month.

How World of Warcraft Devs Launched One of the Biggest Unions in Video Games

Microsoft’s acquisition of Activision Blizzard created an environment that helped workers. Amid layoffs and worries about AI, their efforts could be an indicator of the future of the industry.

Six-Word Sci-Fi: Stories Written by You

Here's this month's prompt, how to submit, and an illustrated archive of past favorites.

What Twisters Gets Right—and Wrong—About Tornado Science

The Twister sequel, which brought in over $80 million at the box office this weekend, is full of good science. But its big reveal is full of spin.

The Inevitability of Big Tech Backing Trump

Silicon Valley, fueled by greed and acting in its own calculated interest, seeks to influence the 2024 presidential election. Political scientist Jared Clemons is certain capitalism won’t save us.

Fortnite Has a Political Violence Problem

In a report shared exclusively with WIRED, the Global Project Against Hate and Extremism says it found more than a dozen user-generated games on Fortnite that featured antisemitism and political violence.
